it needs a sticky bit because it writes to /var

crontab writes a temporary file when you use crontab -e, and then does some consistency checking I think (might not do that, not terribly important for this point though) and then moves it over to /var/spool/ somewhere
/var/spool/cron/crontabs/user
the reason it can access it when you use crontab as a normal user is that it has a sticky bit which means that it has the same permissions as the user which owns it (which is root)
yeah it changes depending on which cron daemon you are using
i checked the permissions of the crontab file "user". it's read write owner, owned by "user"
are you sure? Usually the owner is root and the group is user
owner of the crontabs folder is root, group crontab.

ok yeah that crontab is implemented different than the one I am using but yeah the point is that you can't edit it because you don't have the right privileges one way or another, whereas the crontab binary can because it has a sticky bit
so the crontabs folder and the program both have sticky bits?
no, the program has a sticky bit: -rwsr-xr-x 1 root root 10076 2007-11-15 12:21 /usr/bin/crontab
the s means that it has the privileges of root when it executes which is why it can write the cron files when you can't by yourself
even if it isn't executed by root, it has root's privileges
the s is in group for me.
